author: William Baldwin
title: Best ETFs: Medium-Term Bonds
text:
This group includes funds whose portfolios have a duration (a measure of interest-rate sensitivity) between 4 and 7 years. Either the fund aims narrowly in that range or else it’s a broad-market index fund (covering all maturities) and winds up with a mid-range average duration by default.BlackRock, a cost laggard with its emerging market stock fund, is the cost winner in broad-market bonds. Its iShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond fund ( AGG ) is $30 cheaper over ten years than the similar item from Vanguard, Total Bond Market ( BND ).AGG’s expense ratio is a tad higher than BND’s. How does it win the cost race? By lending out some of the bonds to short-sellers, market makers and arbitragers for a fee. The resulting income lightens the expense burden by 2.8 basis points. Securities lending is one of the strong suits at BlackRock, which sits on $4.7 trillion of assets.Schwab has an attractive bond fund to compete with BND and AGG, U.S. Aggregate Bond ( SCHZ ). Despite its small asset base it lands a cost number only a hair above AGG’s.Rules for the Best ETFs scorecard, and links to 13 categories of funds, can be found here .
